chapter.title: Applications in &ubuntu;
chapter.para: &ubuntu; has a wide selection of applications.

sect1.title: Using and Installing applications
sect1.para: &ubuntu; includes a selection of useful applications which are installed by default. You can start an application by pressing Applications and then selecting an application from one of the categories displayed.

If you would like to install additional applications, press ApplicationsAdd/Remove.... Then, browse the selection of packages available and check the ones which you would like to install. When you have finished selecting packages, press Apply and wait for the installation process to finish.

tip.title: Additional, unsupported software
tip.para: By default, you can only install software which is fully supported in &ubuntu;. To gain access to the collection of unsupported software which is available for &ubuntu;, you can check the Show unsupported applications check box in the Add/Remove... application.

sect1.title: Games
sect1.para: &ubuntu; ships with a modest selection of games to keep you entertained.

sect2.title: AisleRiot Solitaire
sect2.para: AisleRiot is a collection of solitaire card games. Press GameSelect Game... to choose which type of solitaire you would like to play - there are over 80 different games to keep you occupied!
To start AisleRiot, press ApplicationsGamesAisleRiot Solitaire.

sect2.title: Five or More
sect2.para: In Five or More, you must make a line of five (or more) marbles of the same color - the marbles will then disappear from the board. Click a marble to select it (it will start spinning) and then click an empty square to move the marble into that square. After each turn, three new marbles are added to the board. The object of the game is to prevent the board from filling with marbles for as long as possible.
To start Five or More, press ApplicationsGamesFive or More.

sect2.title: Mahjongg
sect2.para: Mahjongg is a tile-matching game. You must select pairs of tiles which are at the edge of the pile - if you pick a pair which match, the tiles will disappear. The object of the game is to make all of the tiles disappear without getting stuck.
To start Mahjongg, press ApplicationsGamesMahjongg.

sect2.title: Optional applications
sect2.para: As well as the default games which come pre-installed with &ubuntu;, there are many hundreds of games which you can optionally install. Below are just a few which are available to you:

listitem.para: LXDoom - classic first person shooting game
GNOME Sudoku - traditional number logic game
Monkey Bubble - explode bubbles of different colours
Atomix - make up molecules by pushing atoms around
GCompris - activities and games for kids

sect2.para: For more information on games available in &ubuntu;, please see the &ubuntu; community pages.

sect1.title: Graphics applications
sect1.para: &ubuntu; ships with several graphics applications, which you can use to manage and edit your photos and pictures.

sect2.title: GIMP Image Editor
sect2.para: The GIMP Image Editor allows you to edit your photos quickly and easily, whether you want to remove a speck of dust or erase an entire building from the picture! With its large collection of filters, you can also apply fun and artistic effects to your images.
To start the GIMP Image Editor, press ApplicationsGraphicsGIMP Image Editor.

sect2.title: F-Spot Photo Manager
sect2.para: The F-Spot Photo Manager makes organizing your photos easy. You can tag, categorise and sort your photos with the minimum of effort. Whether you want to show your photos in a slideshow or publish them online, F-Spot makes it easy.
To start the F-Spot Photo Manager, press ApplicationsGraphicsF-Spot Photo Manager.

sect2.title: Optional applications
sect2.para: &ubuntu; has a wide selection of graphics applications available for you to use. Here are just a few:

listitem.para: Inkscape Vector Illustrator - powerful drawing application for creating graphics and artwork
Scribus - desktop-publishing (DTP) package, which you can use to produce professional-looking publications

sect2.para: For more information on graphics software available in &ubuntu;, please see the &ubuntu; community pages.

sect1.title: Internet applications
sect1.para: &ubuntu; includes a collection of world-class Internet applications to make your on-line experience as effortless as possible.

sect2.title: Firefox Web Browser
sect2.para: Firefox is an award-winning browser which allows you to enjoy the web comfortably and securely. With many novel features, such as live bookmarks, integrated search and tabbed-browsing, Firefox offers one of the best browsing experiences available.
To start the Firefox Web Browser, press ApplicationsInternetFirefox Web Browser, or press the blue globe icon at the top of your screen.

sect2.title: Evolution Mail
sect2.para: Evolution is an easy-to-use personal organizer, which is the default email application in &ubuntu;. It offers a pleasing mix of advanced features and ease of use, designed to keep yourself and your emails organized. Whether you want to keep track of your tasks and appointments or just send and receive email, Evolution is a great choice.
To start Evolution Mail, press ApplicationsInternetEvolution Mail.

sect2.title: Gaim Internet Messenger
sect2.para: Gaim is an instant messaging application with a twist - it allows you to talk to your friends and contacts on all of the major instant messaging networks, such as AIM and MSN, at the same time. While advanced features are not available for some networks, Gaim does a great job of allowing you to chat with your buddies.
To start the Gaim Instant Messenger, press ApplicationsInternetGaim Instant Messenger.

sect2.title: Optional applications
sect2.para: A wide range of excellent Internet software is available for use with &ubuntu;, including these examples:

listitem.para: Liferea Feed Reader - allows you to collect and read Internet news feeds
Ekiga Softphone - make free phone calls over the Internet
Drivel Journal Editor - publish your very own online diary (blog)

sect1.title: Office applications
sect1.para: &ubuntu; includes a full office suite by default, the popular OpenOffice.org suite.

sect2.title: OpenOffice.org Word Processor
sect2.para: The Word Processor allows you to create written documents of any type. Whether you want to send a letter to a relative or type up your lecture notes, Word processor has all of the tools you need to produce a high-quality document.
To start the Word Processor, press ApplicationsOfficeOpenOffice.org Word Processor.

sect2.title: OpenOffice.org Spreadsheet
sect2.para: The Spreadsheet allows you to collect and analyse sets of numbers. These could be anything from your household finances to local football scores - whatever you like. You can perform complex calculations on the numbers and produce illustrative graphs too.
To start the Spreadsheet, press ApplicationsOfficeOpenOffice.org Spreadsheet.

sect2.title: OpenOffice.org Presentation
sect2.para: Do you have a slideshow or presentation to make? OpenOffice.org Presentation allows you to create and show high-impact presentations quickly and easily. A collection of animation effects is available and you can even publish your slideshow on the web.
To start OpenOffice.org Presentation, press ApplicationsOfficeOpenOffice.org Presentation.

sect2.title: Optional applications
sect2.para: &ubuntu; has a great collection of software designed to make office-type work simple. The following are some examples:

listitem.para: gLabels - design your own labels and business cards
GnuCash - keep track of your finances with this personal accounting package
Dia - draw professional diagrams and flowcharts

sect2.para: For more information on office software available in &ubuntu;, please see the &ubuntu; community pages.

sect1.title: Sound and Video applications
sect1.para: You can enjoy music and movies in &ubuntu; using its collection of high-quality multimedia software.

sect2.title: Movie Player
sect2.para: You can use Movie Player to watch movies and video clips, or even to play music. DVD support is optional due to legal issues (see the Restricted Formats page on the &ubuntu; website for more information).
To start Movie Player, press ApplicationsSound & VideoMovie Player, or simply double-click a movie file.

sect2.title: Rhythmbox Music Player
sect2.para: Rhythmbox is much more than just a music player. Not only does it boast features such as automatic playlists, instant music search and drag-and-drop queuing, but it can even handle podcasts, share music over a network and integrate with the online Last.fm service. What more could you ask for?
To start Rhythmbox, press ApplicationsSound & VideoRhythmbox Music Player.

sect2.title: Sound Juicer CD Extractor
sect2.para: Sound Juicer can be used to both play and extract audio CDs. If you have an Internet connection, it will even fetch the names of the songs on your CD for you.
To start Sound Juicer, press ApplicationsSound & VideoSound Juicer CD Extractor, or simply insert an audio CD.

sect2.title: Serpentine Audio CD Creator
sect2.para: Serpentine allows you to make your own compilation CDs. Simply drag and drop songs from Rhythmbox into Serpentine, insert a blank CD and then press Write to Disc. Your new CD will be ready in no time!
To start Serpentine, press ApplicationsSound & VideoSerpentine Audio CD Creator, or insert a blank CD and press Make Audio CD on the screen which should appear.

sect2.title: Optional applications
sect2.para: &ubuntu; has a massive collection of multimedia applications at your disposal - below are a few examples:

listitem.para: Jokosher and Audacity - record, edit and mix your own music
Pitivi - record and edit your video footage
Banshee - organize and play your music, then sync it with your digital audio player

sect2.para: For more information on office software available in &ubuntu;, please see the &ubuntu; community pages.
